revision.text:
The '''history of Hungarian animation''' begins in 1914 and carries through to the modern day. Starting with short promotional cartoons prior to the two World Wars, Hungarian animation underwent a sporadic and halting development during the turbulent war years which were characterized in large part by the emigration of much of the field's top talent. This exodus slowed dramatically during the 1950s when the [[Hungarian Communist Party]] took power and the [[Iron Curtain]] took shape.
With Communism came nationalization of the Hungarian animation studio—a fact that was to prove a mixed blessing for the nascent industry. While political pressures would strongly dictate the kinds of topics that animation could cover in the early years, state funding meant that even the relatively small postwar nation would be able to prove itself on the international stage.<ref>Hankiss, Elemér. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/regi/2000/articles/essays/dizsreri.hu.html A kiválóság szigete]''. FilmKultúra. 2000.</ref><ref name=dizseri>Dizseri, Eszter. ''Kockáról kockára : a magyar animáció krónikája 1948-1998''. Balassi Kiadó. Budapest. 1999. {{ISBN|978-963-506-289-8}}</ref> Indeed, subsequent to the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956|1956 revolution]], the softening effects of [[Goulash Communism]] helped enable artists to begin to express themselves such that by the late 1970s, Pannónia Film Stúdió would rank among the top 5 major cartoon studios alongside [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney]], [[Hanna-Barbera]], [[Soyuzmultfilm]], and [[Toei Animation|Toei]].<ref name=lendvai>Lendvai, Erzsi. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/regi/articles/essays/anim.hu.html A magyar animációs film]'' (English: "[https://web.archive.org/web/20080208021418/http://www.filmkultura.iif.hu:8080/articles/essays/anim.en.html Animated cartoons in Hungary]"). FilmKultúra. 1996.</ref>
With the end of Communism in 1989, state control of the animation industry dropped away and market forces prompted the rise of numerous independent animation studios. Lacking state funding and receiving mixed international response, Hungarian animation studios today have had to develop financing strategies consisting largely of working as production and development companies performing labor-intensive animation activities such as compositioning and inking for foreign studios. Despite this, Hungarian films continue to be produced every few years.
==Overview== The history of Hungarian animation extends from its origin in István Kató Kiszly's 1914 cut-out caricatures to the modern time. Although a few boldly experimental films were made in the early years, it would not be until the 1930s that actual animation studios would be formed (under figures like [[Gyula Macskássy]] and [[János Halász]]) to produce promotional material in the form of [[newsreel]]s and advertisements. International conflicts during both world wars as well as turbulent political climates in the pre-[[Iron Curtain]] period led to the emigration of many of Hungary's animation artists who famously established themselves in places like France, the U.K., and America. During the Communist era, all animation efforts are nationalized first as Magyar Szinkronfilmgyártó Vállalat in 1948 and later as [[Pannónia Film Stúdió]] in 1959. State control of animation on the one hand constrained artistic freedom of expression while simultaneously ensuring the survival of the medium.<ref name=lendvai/>
During the 1950s, the first modern generation of Hungarian animators came to prominence, creating primarily short animations depicting the Hungarian folk tales and legends that would be a politically safe mainstay of Hungarian animation output throughout the Communist era. This generation would be responsible for creating the first colored animation. A second generation of animators would emerge in the 1960s under the less repressive system of [[Goulash Communism]], and sociopolitical sentiment was for the first time gently hinted at as cartoons developed philosophical themes characterized by morbidity and black humor. Foreign animation studios began to reach out to Pannónia Film Stúdió during this period to subcontract some of the more laborious elements of cartoon production such as compositioning and inking. This introduced the concept of cartoon series/serials, and soon a number of Hungarian serials were created introducing the country's first recognizable cartoon character stars. This period also saw the production of the first [[adult animation]]. The 1970s saw the rise of a third generation of animators even more intent on commentary on the social conditions in the country. Animations during this period were often marked by a muted subsurface emphasis on anxiety and a claustrophobic fear of persecution while the animation works of older (first and second generation) animators tended to emphasize morality and a development of the grotesque. This third generation would see the emergence of the country's first feature-length films as Pannónia Film Stúdió rose to international renown as one of the top 5 major cartoon studios alongside [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney]], [[Hanna-Barbera]], [[Soyuzmultfilm]], and [[Toei Animation|Toei]].<ref name=lendvai/>
The 1980s would prove to be a peak of Hungarian animation efforts. Increasingly bold use of irony and allegory portrayed the Hungarian condition under Communist rule and during this period a number of Hungarian films received high accolades and prestigious awards including [[Ferenc Rofusz]]' 1981 Oscar for ''[[A Légy]]'' ("The Fly").<ref name=howard>Howard, Doug. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20090312002759/http://www.amcham.hu/BusinessHUngary/15-01/articles/15-01_28.asp Beyond the frames: Will this art survive?]''. Business Hungary. Vol.15, No.1. American Chamber of Commerce in Hungary. January 2001.</ref> The decade would also mark a renaissance in technical experimentation with the exploration of many non-traditional graphic media such as plasticine, sand, coal, textiles, and computer animation. During this period the first feature-length films based on serials were created and proved to be quite popular.<ref name=lendvai/> In 1989, Communist rule was cast off and with it State control of the animation arts in 1990. Due to free market pressures, a number of independent animation studios sprang up in the wake. The novel issue of commercial financing proved to be a complex one as new studios struggled to make ends meet. A variety of solutions were adopted ranging from the active courting of foreign contract work, to specialization in the labor-intensive traditional hand-animation forms, to employee ownership.<ref name=howard/> In 2002, the new Hungarian government began to take a role in the medium as well with funding from the Ministry of National Cultural Heritage going toward the development of further animations of Hungarian folk tales and legends which since the Communist era have become a source of national pride.<ref name=howard/>
==Pre-animation history== *1709 - Professor István Simándi of [[Sárospatak]] assembled and used his own projector (a variant of the [[magic lantern]]) for educational purposes. With this machine Simándi aimed to bring about the same animation effect as [[Transparency (projection)|transparencies]] do today.<ref>Bartók, István. Kőszeghy, Péter, ed. ''[http://rec.iti.mta.hu/rec.iti/Members/szerk/mamul-lx-book/MAMUL-LX.pdf Magyar Művelődéströrténeti Lexikon LX.]''. "Laterna Magica". Balassi Kiado. Pp.121-122. 2011. {{ISBN|978-963-506-789-3}}</ref> *1889 - Hungarian-born Adolph Cukor (better known as [[Adolph Zukor]]) emigrates to the United States where he becomes invested in cinema in 1903. By 1912, Cukor established [[Famous Players Film Company]] which in turn became [[Famous Players-Lasky]] and eventually [[Paramount Pictures]]. As president of Paramount, Zukor produced numerous [[Color Classics]] cartoons during the 1930s.<ref>James, Ryan. ''Frommer's Budapest And The Best Of Hungary: Volume 759 of Frommer's Complete''. John Wiley & Sons. 2010. {{ISBN|978-0-470-55126-4}}</ref><ref name=dawson>Dawson, Bryan. ''[http://www.americanhungarianfederation.org/FamousHungarians//filmartsandmedia.htm Nobel Prize Winners & Famous Hungarians]''. American Hungarian Federation. 2006.</ref> *1899 - Hungarian-born Margit Winkler (better known as [[Margaret J. Winkler]]) emigrates to the United States where in 1918 she becomes the first female film producer, playing an essential role in the production of ''[[Out of the Inkwell]]'', and the early history of ''[[Felix the Cat]]'', ''[[Krazy Kat]]'' and Disney's ''[[Oswald the Lucky Rabbit]]'' series with the help of her husband [[Charles Mintz]].<ref name=orosz>Orosz, Márton. ''[http://www.kaff.hu/files/documents/Marton_Orosz_KAFF_2011_Vissza_a_szulofoldre_Back_to_the_homeland.pdf Vissza a szülőföldre! / Back to the Homeland!]''. 10th [[Kecskeméti Animáció Film Fesztivál]] (KAFF) 2011. {{ISBN|978-963-08-1576-5}}</ref><ref name=vasV>Orosz, Anna Ida and Orosz, Márton. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/keptar/cikkep/magyarok_amerikaban.pps Vissza a szülőföldre! - V. rész - Magyarok Amerikában]''. FilmKultura. 2011.</ref>
==Early animation efforts== The earliest period of Hungarian animation was marked by experimentation and the development of the first animation studio headed by pioneers, [[Gyula Macskássy]] and [[János Halász]].<ref name=beckerman>Beckerman, Howard. ''Animation: the whole story''. Allworth Press. 1 September 2003. {{ISBN|978-1-58115-301-9}}</ref> Animations were primarily promotional in nature although throughout the 1930s more and more complex narrative structures were developed. Between 1932 and 1945, 150 promotional cartoons are produced including ''Családi kávépótló'' ("Family Coffee Substitute"), ''Estétől reggelig'' ("Evening to Morning"), ''A láthatatlan vendég'' ("Invisible Visitor"), ''Zeusz inkognitóban'' ("Zeus in Cognito"), ''Vidám suszterinas'' ("The hilarious shoemaker's boy"), ''Szerencsés flottás'' ("Lucky Jim"), and ''Izzó szerelem'' ("Glowing Love")<ref name=lendvai/><ref name=koltai>Koltai, Ágnes. ''[http://www.filmvilag.hu/cikk.php?cikk_id=6059 Kecskeméti Animációs Filmszemle]''. Filmvilág Krónika. August 1985.</ref> During the lead-up to World War II and the turbulent war years, Hungary saw an exodus of artists and filmmakers, particularly among the Hungarian Jewish population. Seeking to continue their art in less politically fraught climates, several Hungarian cartoonists began to establish studios abroad.<ref name=lendvai/><ref name=wright/>
*1914 - István Kató Kiszly, creator of weekly news bulletins, creates Hungary's first animated film—an animated cut-out cartoon entitled ''Zrib Ödön''.<ref name=cunningham>Cunningham, John. ''Hungarian cinema: from coffee house to multiplex''. Wallflower Press. 2004. {{ISBN|978-1-903364-79-6}}</ref> For the next few years he creates several more cut-out cartoons including ''János Vitez'' (1916)<ref name=cunningham/> and the caricatures of Marcell Vértes made in 1918 for the evening news bulletin entitled "Evening"<ref name=wright>Wright, Jean Ann. ''Animation writing and development: from script development to pitch''. Focal Press. 31 December 2004. {{ISBN|978-0-240-80549-8}}</ref> He would go on to animate ''Rómeó és Júlia'' ("Romeo and Juliet") in 1921, and ''Bogárorféum'' ("The Music Hall of Insects") in 1932.<ref name=napochka>Napochka, Haruko. ''[http://napochka.com/anim_top_hu.html#anim_his01 Magyar Rajfilm Történet A Dióhéjban]'' (English: "[http://napochka.com/anim_top_en.html#anim_his01 Animation History In Hungary]"). Napochka. 26 February 2011.</ref> *1914 - Painter, Móric Gábor contracts to make and produces a short animation which is lost during World War I.<ref name=orosz/> *1920s - Hungarian [[Dada]]ist, György Gerö creates a series of experimental animations including a short film depicting a blooming cactus.<ref name=orosz/> He would avoid political prison during the 1940s by committing himself to an asylum as a neurotic. Here, all traces of him were lost.<ref>Checefsky, Bruce. ''[http://www.seesawpictures.com/bela Béla]''. Seesaw Pictures. 2011.</ref> *1920 - Bohemian-born Austro-Hungarian, [[Berthold Bartosch]] emigrates to Berlin where he worked with [[Lotte Reininger]] on silhouette animation techniques before moving to Paris in 1930 to create ''[[The Idea (1932 film)|L'Idée]]''. *1922 - Hungarian-born Gyula Engel (anglicized as [[Jules Engel]]) emigrates to Chicago. He would move to Los Angeles in 1937 to work with Margit Winkler, eventually settling in Hollywood in the late 1930s working for Disney on ''Fantasia'' and ''Bambi'' and later founding [[United Productions of America|UPA]].<ref name=vasV/><ref name=wright/><ref>[[Steven Subotnick|Subotnick, Steven]]. ''Animation in the Home Digital Studio: Creation to Distribution''. Focal Press. 6 January 2003. {{ISBN|978-0-240-80474-3}}</ref> *1922 - Andor Weininger creates the earliest surviving animated film storyboard script made by a Hungarian.<ref name=orosz/> *1924 - Hungarian-born stop-motion animator, István Rajk (Gallicized as Étienne Raïk) settles in Paris.<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasIV>Orosz, Anna Ida and Orosz, Márton. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/keptar/cikkep/magyarok_franciaorszagban.pps Vissza a szülőföldre! - IV. rész - Magyarok Franciaországban] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106144424/http://www.filmkultura.hu/keptar/cikkep/magyarok_franciaorszagban.pps |date=2013-11-06 }}''. FilmKultura. 2011.</ref> *1928 - Graphic artist, [[Gyula Macskássy]] meets [[János Halász]] at Műhely, a [[Bauhaus]] art studio run by Sándor Bortnyik.<ref name=lendvai/><ref name=napochka/> Here, short experimental animations are produced under Bortnyik's direction including a piece drawn by Halász depicting a chicken walking in front of an egg—originally intended to become part of the chicken [[csárdás]] scene in Bortnyik's unreleased ''Királyfi és a Hattyútündér'' ("The Prince and the Swan Fairy").<ref name=vasI>Orosz, Anna Ida and Orosz, Márton. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/keptar/cikkep/halas.pps Vissza a szülőföldre! - I. rész - Halász János - John Halas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512161202/http://www.filmkultura.hu/keptar/cikkep/halas.pps |date=2015-05-12 }}''. FilmKultura. 2011.</ref> Only a few fragments of Bortnyk's films remain today.<ref name=orosz/> *1929 - Painter, Róbert Berény joins Endre Gál's special effects [[Atelier (art)|atelier]], Pantofilm, to produce limited animations including ''Az okos kandúr'' ("The Clever Tomcat"), and ''Sabol rovarirtó'' ("Sabol Insect Repellent").<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasI/> *1930 - Emigre artist, Győző Vásárhelyi (better known as [[Victor Vasarely]]) establishes himself in Paris where he develops his style of kinematic and kinetic art through the use of optical illusion and methods like [[flip book|flip animation]].<ref>Grimes, William. ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/18/movies/robert-breer-pioneer-of-avant-garde-animation-dies-at-84.html Robert Breer, Pioneer of Avant-Garde Animation, Dies at 84]''. New York Times. 17 August 2011.</ref> He is joined briefly in the early 1930s by Imre Hajdú who works together with him to paint background sets.<ref name=vasIV/> *1930 - János Halász produces short interstitial animations together with [[György Marczincsák]] at studio Hunnia.<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasIII>Orosz, Anna Ida and Orosz, Márton. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/keptar/cikkep/george_pal.pps Vissza a szülőföldre! - III. rész - George Pal, azaz Pál György]''. FilmKultura. 2011.</ref> These animations mostly consisted of title sequences and animated inserts to adapt foreign animations for Hungarian audiences.<ref name=vasI/> *Early 1930s - Emigre artists, Lenke Perényi (better known as Madeleine Steinfield) and Vilma Kiss (variously known as Vilma de Kiss, Vilma de Kish, and Wilma de Quiche) settle in Paris to produce French animations.<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasIV/> *1932 - Together with graphic artist Félix Kassowitz, Macskássy and Halász form Hungary's first animation studio, Coloriton, which existed for 4 years, producing high-quality promotion-oriented animations for television and cinema including ''Boldog király kincse'' ("The Treasure of the Joyful King").<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasI/> The three men are joined by caricaturist Ernő Szénássy and musician Gusztáv Ilosvay.<ref name=lendvai/><ref name=napochka/> Toward the end of Coloriton's existence, the studio expanded briefly into the UK where the daughter studio, British Colour Cartoon Films Limited, was formed under Halász' supervision.<ref name=vasI/> *1932 - Emigre cartoonist, Imre Hajdú (better known by his stage name, [[Jean Image]]—"Image" is based upon the French pronunciation of "Im-Haj", the initial syllables of his full name) establishes himself in France to produce nearly two dozen animated films during his lifetime.<ref name=wright/><ref name=vasIV/> *1933 - Imre Tóth (better known as [[Amerigo Tot]]) works on [[The Adventures of Pinocchio (1936 film)|an animated adaptation of ''Pinocchio'']].<ref name=orosz/> The film has since been lost. *1934 - Emigre cartoonist, György Pál Marczincsák (better known by his stage name, [[George Pal]]) first moves to Germany where he creates ''Habakuk'' and ''Der Kollege'' while developing the concept of [[Puppetoons]] (originally called Pal-dolls).<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasIII/> He would move shortly afterward to Holland for Philips to create ''[[Philips Cavalcade]]'' (1934) and ''The Sleeping Beauty'' (1935), and then to Paris and then Eindhoven where he founded and worked at puppet animation studio Dollywood until 1939.<ref name=vasIII/> Establishing himself in Hollywood in 1940, Pal worked for Paramount where he produced several more shorts in the Puppetoons series and won several Oscars.<ref name=beckerman/><ref name=wright/> *1934 - Artist [[Béla Balázs]] emigrates to the Soviet Union where he creates "A Vor" ({{lang-ru|italic= yes|Вор}}).<ref name=vasV/> *1936 - Cartoonist János Halász (anglicized as [[John Halas]]) emigrates to found [[Halas and Batchelor|Halas and Batchelor Studio]] in London with his wife, [[Joy Batchelor]] in 1940.<ref name=beckerman/><ref name=lendvai2>Lendvai, Erzsi. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/regi/2002/articles/profiles/halas.hu.html Egy halhatatlanságra vágyó animátor]''. FilmKultúra. 2002.</ref> Here he finds the political freedom to produce a number of works including his most famous work, ''[[Animal Farm (1954 film)|Animal Farm]]'' (1954).<ref name=napochka/><ref name=vasI/> He would later be granted an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in 1972, would become the president of [[ASIFA]] in 1979, and would play an essential role in Hungary's first three animated film festivals ([[Kecskeméti Animáció Film Fesztivál|KAFF]] events).<ref name=lendvai2/> *Late 1930s - Hungarian animation within Hungary continues through the efforts of animators like István Balogh, Viktor Kálmán, Félix Kassowitz, and István Valker. During this period Valker famously creates ''Orosz álom'' ("Russian Dream"), ''Tiroli tánc'' ("Dance of Tyrol"), and ''Sztepptánc'' ("Step-Dance"), a series of three [[Films with live action and animation|live action and animation]] pictures starring child actress, Ági Polly. Valker's techniques were developed independent of prior similar efforts abroad, but in Hungary the concept was considered unworkable, and the films met with poor reception.<ref name=lendvai/><ref name=napochka/> *1938-1944 - Valker creates ''Csavargó szerencséje'' ("A Vagabond's Luck") and, with the help of Teréz David, ''A molnár, a fia meg a szamár'' ("The Miller, The Miller's Son, and the Donkey"),<ref name=koltai/> the latter of which would be completed during the bombing campaign that preceded the 1944 [[Siege of Budapest]].<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasII>Orosz, Anna Ida and Orosz, Márton. ''[http://www.filmkultura.hu/keptar/cikkep/kozelka_mocsary_david.pps Vissza a szülőföldre! - II. rész - Kozelka Kálmán, Mocsáry Ida, Dávid Teréz]''. FilmKultura. 2011.</ref> *1940 - László Tubay creates ''A kis balta'' ("Small Axe")<ref name=lendvai/> *1946 - István Bessenyei creates ''Holdszerenád'' ("Moon-Serenade")<ref name=lendvai/> *1946 - Emigre cartoonist, Péter Mihály Földes (anglicized as [[Peter Foldes]]) established himself in England where he works in collaboration with János Halász before marrying his wife Joan Foldes and establishing an independent studio.<ref name=lenburg>Lenburg, Jeff. ''Who's Who in Animated Cartoons: An International Guide to Film & Television's Award-Winning and Legendary Animators''. Hal Leonard Corporation. 2006. {{ISBN|978-1-55783-671-7}}</ref> Here the couple create the politically charged ''A Short Vision'' which won critical acclaim on release in 1956. The couple live briefly in Paris before settling in Canada to produce a number of films for the National Film Board of Canada including the Oscar-nominated ''Hunger'' (1975).<ref name=vasV/> *1948 - All film-making is nationalized by the [[Hungarian Communist Party]].<ref name=napochka/><ref name=kowe/> During the next few years Macskássy worked independently within national channels to create a series of educational films including ''Az egér és az oroszlán'' ("The Mouse and the Lion"), ''Hol az a macska?'' ("Where's that Cat?"), and ''Uhuka, a kis bagoly'' ("Uhuka, the Little Owl"). A number of short films were released at a slow rate by other artists as well. *1948 - Zoltán Olcsai Kiss creates the puppet-animation, ''Megy a juhász a szamáron'' ("Shepherd's Riding a Donkey"),<ref name=napochka/> the first animated film following nationalization of the industry.<ref name=kowe>''[http://corp.kw2007.com/pannonia PannóniaFilm, Ltd.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111228162229/http://corp.kw2007.com/pannonia |date=2011-12-28 }}''. KoWe International Film & TV Business Network. (Also available: ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20091201134736/http://www.mediaguide.hu/pannoniafilm/story.html Múltunk: 50 év az animáció élvonalában / History: 50 Years in the Forefront of Animation]''. [[Pannónia Film Stúdió|PannoniaFilm]].) 2007.</ref> He creates ''Vitamin ABC'' two years later in 1950.<ref name=lendvai/> *1950 - Emigre cartoonist, Teréz David (anglicized as [[Tissa David]]), moves to Paris, eventually establishing herself in New York City in 1955.<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasII/>
==Modern animation==
===First generation animation=== Folktale animation is common and this period sees a rise in Hungarian animation establishing such animators as [[József Nepp]], [[Attila Dargay]], Tibor Csermák, Gábor Kovásznai, József Gémes, Szabolcs Szabó, György Várnai, [[Marcell Jankovics]], Péter Szoboszlay, [[Zsolt Richly]], [[Sándor Reisenbüchler]], Béla Vajda, Tamás Szabó Sipos, János Mata, and also puppet animators like Ottó Foky and István Imre.<ref name=lendvai/>
*1941-1951 - Gyula Macskássy and Edit Fekete create the first color animation, ''A kiskakas gyémánt félkrajcárja'' ("The Little Cock's Diamond Halfpenny").<ref name=kowe/> The film begins life as a black and white production in the Cartoon and Puppet Department of the wartime Newsreel and Documentary Studios, but due to delays relating to the war, the film isn't completed until 1951. *1952 - Gyula Macskássy creates ''Erdei sportverseny'' ("Sport Competition in the Forest").<ref name=lendvai/> *1953 - Gyula Macskássy and Edit Fekete create ''Kutyakötelesség'' ("A Puppy's Strict Obligation").<ref name=lendvai/> *1955 - Gyula Macskássy creates ''Két bors ökröcske'' ("Two Peppercorn Steers").<ref name=dizseri/> *1956 - With the help of Hungarian emigre cartoonist Richard Fehsl, cartoonists Kalman Kozelka (anglicized as Kali Kozelka) and his wife, Ida Mocsary (better known as Ducika Mocsary) flee to Austria as political refugees. They settle in the Netherlands in the 1970s founding Kozelka Film Studios.<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasII/> *1956 - Emigre cartoonist, Elek Imrédy exits the country to settle in the Canada.<ref name=orosz/><ref name=vasII/> *1958 - Gyula Macskássy creates ''A telhetetlen méhecske'' ("The Greedy Bee").<ref name=lendvai/> *1960 - Gyula Macskássy creates ''A ceruza és a radír'' ("Pencil and Rubber") and ''Párbaj'' ("Duel") which are the first Hungarian films to receive international acclaim.<ref name=dizseri/> ''Párbaj'' is awarded the [[Jury Prize (Cannes Film Festival)|Special Jury Prize]] at the 1961 [[Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name=kowe/>
===Second-generation animation=== Foreign animation teams begin to reach out to Pannónia Film Studio as a way to cut costs on some of the more labor-intensive aspects of cartoon production. In domestic productions, however, with the artistic community under strain from an authoritarian Communist government, morbidity and black humor become more common as cartoons were used to hint at and reflect the philosophy and conditions of the day. Due to Western influence, such cartoon serials emerged as Gyula Macskássy and György Várnai's ''Peti és a gépember'' ("Peti and the Robot"), ''Marci és a Cső'' ("Marci in the Jungle"), ''Vili és Bütyök'' ("Vili and Bütyök"), ''Üzenet a jövőből'' ("Messages from the Future"), ''[[Kérem a következőt!]]'' ("Next, Please!"), ''Varjúdombi mesék'' ("Tales from Crow Hill"), Tamás Szabó Sipos's ''Magyarázom...'' ("Let Me Explain..."), and Ottó Foky's ''Egy világhírű vadász emlékiratai'' ("The Magic Snake"). With the emergence of cartoon serials came the country's first recognizable cartoon character stars such as Gergő, Peti, Gustav, [[Frakk]], Kukori and Kotkoda, Mirr-Murr, Elek Mekk, Dr. Bubó, Mikrobi, [[Kockásfülű nyúl]], TV Maci, and [[Mézga család]], each of whom featured in several cartoons. Animation for adult entertainment also emerged during this period with such series as Gyula Macskássy and György Várnai's ''Ember és ember'' ("Man and Human").<ref name=lendvai/><ref name=wright/> * 1961 – [[József Nepp]] creates ''Szenvedély'' ("Passion"). * 1961 – Tibor Csermák creates ''A piros pöttyös labda'' ("The Ball with White Dots"),<ref name=wright/> which wins the 1961 [[Venice Film Festival]] [[Golden Lion]] for best Children's Film.<ref name=kowe/> * 1961 – Under Gyula Macskássy's leadership, work is completed for the Western film series, ''[[Arthur! and the Square Knights of the Round Table|Arthur]]'' (itself directed by emigre Zoran Janjic). * 1962 – Inspired by their work on ''Arthur'', Gyula Macskássy and György Várnai create ''Peti és a gépember'' ("Peti and the Robot"), the first cartoon in what was to become the ''Peti'' series (26 episodes, 1963–1967).<ref name=kowe/> This marks Hungary's first animated series. * 1963 – Gábor Kovásznai creates ''Monológ'' ("Monologue") which pushes the visual artistry of the medium. * 1964 – Gábor Kovásznai creates ''Átváltozások'' ("Metamorphoses") which pushes the visual artistry of the medium. * 1964 – Ottó Foky creates ''TV Maci'' ("TV Little Bear"). Inspired by the puppet-animations of Czech director [[Jiří Trnka]], the popular TV Maci becomes the mascot of the Hungarian children's TV program ''Esti mese'' ("Bed Time Story").<ref name=napochka/> * 1966 - József Nepp creates ''Öt perc gyilkosság'' ("Murder For Five Minutes") * 1966 - Gyula Macskássy and György Várnai create ''Tíz deka halhatatlanság'' ("Ten Dekagrams of Immortality") * 1967 - Gábor Kovásznai creates ''Hamlet'', which pushes the visual artistry of the medium. * 1968 - József Gémes creates ''Koncertisszimo'' ("Concertissimo"), one of the first animated paintings.<ref name=kowe/> * 1968 - [[Sándor Reisenbüchler]] creates ''A Nap és a Hold elrablása'' ("Sun and Moon Carried Off"), which is considered to expand the narrative sophistication of the medium while introducing experimental collage techniques.<ref name=dizseri/><ref name=kowe/> * 1969 - [[Marcell Jankovics]] creates ''Hídavatás'' ("A Ceremonial Opening of a Bridge") * 1970 - Gyula Macskássy creates ''Az öngyilkos'' ("Self-Destroyer") * 1971 - József Gémes creates ''Temetés'' ("Funeral")
===Third generation animation=== With the artistic community still under government pressure, a third generation of films is marked by a muted subsurface emphasis on anxiety and a claustrophobic fear of persecution. Older (first and second generation) animators tended to emphasize morality and a development of the grotesque.<ref name=lendvai/>
*1970-1971 - Marcell Jankovics creates ''Mással beszélnek'' ("The Line is Engaged"). *1970 - The first feature-length cartoon script is created with the title ''Gusztáv bárkája'' ("Gustav's Boat") however the film is never produced. *1971 - The animation workshop, Kecskeméti Animációs Filmstúdió, is founded as a subsidiary of Pannónia Film Studio. Shortly after this, another workshop would be established in [[Pécs]].<ref name=napochka/><ref name=kowe/><ref name=kaff>''[http://www.kaff.hu/content/show/2 A KAFF története]''. [[Kecskeméti Animáció Film Fesztivál]]. 2011.</ref> *1972 - Sándor Reisenbüchler creates ''Az 1812-es év'' ("The Year 1812") to win a [[Palme d'Or du court métrage]] in Cannes.<ref name=kowe/> He would go on to create ''Holdmese'' ("Moon-Flight") in 1975, and ''Pánik'' ("Panic") in 1978. *1973 - Béla Vajda creates ''Jócselekedetek'' ("Good-Deeds") *1973 - György Kovásznai creates ''Ca Ira'' ("It Will Work"). He would go on to create the feature-length musical cartoon, ''Habfürdő'' ("Foam Bath") in 1979.<ref name=dizseri/> *1973 - Kati Macskássy greatly develops the genre of children's animation with ''Gombnyomásra'' ("Push Button") and later ''Nekem az élet teccik nagyon...'' ("I Think Life's Great Fun") in 1976. The latter film won 1st Prize at [[Melbourne International Animation Festival|Melbourne]].<ref name=kowe/> *1973 - Marcell Jankovics creates the first feature-length Hungarian film, ''János Vitéz'' ("Johnny Corncob")<ref name=kowe/> based on the poetry of [[Sándor Petőfi]].<ref name=napochka/> He would go on to create the 1975 Academy Award nominee, ''[[Sisyphus (film)|Sisyphus]]'',<ref name=lenburg/> and later ''[[Küzdők]]'' (''Fight'') which won a [[Palme d'Or du court métrage]] in Cannes.<ref name=kowe/> These efforts were followed by the ''[[Magyar népmesék]]'' ("Hungarian Folk Tales") series in 1978.<ref name=napochka/> *1973 - Bill Feigenbaum and József Gémes create the feature-length ''[[Hugó a víziló]]'' ("Hugo, the Hippopotamus") under the commission of American Fabergé Brut.<ref name=dizseri/> *1975 - Ottó Foky creates ''Babfilm'' ("Scenes With Beans") to win the Grand Prix at the Lausanne Film Festival.<ref name=kowe/> *1975 - Emigre cartoonist [[Gábor Csupó]] moves to Sweden to escape the oppressive conditions of Soviet-era Hungary. He soon forms Klasky Csupo Studio with his wife, the Hungarian-born animator [[Arlene Klasky]].<ref name=lenburg/> The couple would go on to produce shows such as ''The Simpsons'' and ''Rugrats'', and would win numerous Emmy awards for their efforts in animation.<ref name=dawson/> *1976 - Péter Szoboszlay creates ''Hé, te!'' ("Hey, You") *1976 - Ferenc Varsányi creates ''Nagy mulatság'' ("The Big Blow-Out"). He would later help to further develop the genre of children's animation with ''Irka-firka'' ("Graffiti") in 1977. *1976 - Attila Dargay creates the feature-length ''[[Mattie the Goose-boy (1977 film)|Lúdas Matyi]]'' ("Matty the Gooseboy") *1977 - István Kovács creates ''Változó idők'' ("Changing Times") *1977 - Csaba Szórady creates ''Rondinó'' ("Rondino") *1978 - Pál Varga Géza creates ''Fair Play''
===The 1980s=== A decade considered to have been responsible for the peak of Hungarian animation, the 1980s would see increasingly bold use of irony and allegory in portraying the Hungarian condition under Communist rule and would mark a renaissance in technical experimentation with the exploration of many non-traditional graphic media. Of particular note, several new experimental serials emerged during this period including Sándor Békési's ''Vázák meséi'' ("Tales of Vases"), Csaba Varga's ''Szekrénymesék'' ("The Wardrobe's Tales"), and plasticine animations including Csaba Varga's ''Auguszta'' ("Augusta") and [[Ferenc Cakó]]'s ''Zénó''. Feature-length films were made of a number of serials from the 1960s and 1970s, including Szabolcs Szabó and József Haui's ''Vízipók-csodapók'' ("Water-Spider, Wonder-Spider"), Ottó Foky's ''Misi Mókus kalandjai'' ("The Adventures of Sam the Squirrel"), [[Attila Dargay]]'s ''[[Vuk (film)|Vuk]]'', and Pál Tóth's ''Leo és Fred'' ("Leo and Fred"). New series were also launched including Attila Dargay's ''Pom-pom meséi'' ("Tales of Pom Pom") and ''A nagy hó-hó-horgász'' ("The Grrreat Angler"), Ferenc Cakó's ''Sebaj Tóbiás'' ("Never Mind Toby"), László Ujváry Jr.'s ''Mesék Mátyás királyról'' ("Tales about King Matthias"), Marcell Jankovics' ''Mondák a magyar történelemből'' ("Hungarian Historical Legends"), Zsolt Richly's ''Fabulák'' ("Fables") and ''Kíváncsi Fáncsi'' ("Curious Fáncsi"), Tibor Hernádi's ''Animália'' ("Animalia"), [[Líviusz Gyulai]]'s ''Tinti kalandjai'' ("Tinti's Adventures") and ''Kentaurfi kalandjai'' ("Adventures of Fanny the Elephant"), Tamás Baksa's ''Trombi és a tűzmanó'' ("Trombi and the Fiery Imp"), and Ferenc Varsányi's ''Csepke'' ("Droplet"). Animators making a name for themselves in this period included Ferenc Varsányi, Miklós Kaim, István Kovács, Elek Lisziák, Zsolt Richly, Kati Macskássy, [[Béla Ternovszky]], Tibor Hernádi, László Ujváry, Ferenc Cakó, László Hegyi Füstös, Csaba Varga, Ágnes Pásztor, Mária Horváth, [[István Orosz]], and [[Ferenc Rofusz]].<ref name=lendvai/>
*1980 - Csaba Varga creates ''Ebéd'' ("The Luncheon"), the first in a series starring Augusztá the rubber lady. He would go on to create the artistically significant ''A szél'' ("The Wind") in 1985. *1980 - Béla Vajda creates ''Moto Perpetuo'' to win the [[Palme d'Or du court métrage]] at the Cannes Film Festival.<ref name=kowe/> He goes on to create the social message film, ''Teljesítmény és siker'' ("Performance and Success") in 1982. *1980 - Mária Horváth creates ''Ajtó'' ("Doors") and later the artistically significant ''Az éjszaka csodái'' ("Miracles of the Night") in 1982. *1980 - Marcell Jankovics creates the experimental feature-length film, ''[[Fehérlófia]]'' ("The Son of the White Horse") *1981 - Third generation cartoonist, [[Ferenc Rofusz]] creates ''[[A Légy]]'' ("The Fly"), a darkly allegorical tale about loss of freedom and the consequences of desperate attempts to escape. The film is well-received internationally and it wins the 1981 Academy Award for best animated short film.<ref name=kowe/> Rofusz would go on to create ''Gravitáció'' ("Gravitation") in 1984 before emigrating to Toronto to work at [[Nelvana|Nelvana Studios]] in 1988. *1981 - [[János Kass]]' ''Dilemma'' becomes the first fully digital animated film and is nominated for a [[Palme d'Or du court métrage]] for Best Short Film at the Cannes Film Festival. *1982 - [[Ferenc Cakó]] creates ''Autótortúra'' ("Motorture") and, later the same year, ''Ad Astra''. *1982 - Miklós Kaim creates ''Kutyagumi'' ("Mad Rubber Dog") *1982 - László Hegyi Füstös creates ''Statisztikai zsebfilm'' ("Statistical Pocketfilm"), a social message film *1982 - György Kovásznai and Elek Lisziák create ''Riportré'' ("Reportrait"), a social message film *1982 - Ottó Foky releases ''Misi Mókus kalandjai'' ("The Adventures of Sam the Squirrel") *1982 - József Gémes creates the experimental feature-length film, ''[[Daliás idők]]'' ("Heroic Times"). This would be followed by ''[[Vili, a veréb]]'' ("Willy the Sparrow") in 1988.<ref name=kowe/> *1982 - Pannónia Film Studio produces the French film, ''[[Les Maîtres du temps]]'' by director [[René Laloux]] *1983 - Atilla Csáji creates the experimental laser animation, ''A hatodik vagy a hetedik'' ("Sixth or Seventh...") *1983 - Annamária Zoltán creates the experimental textile animation, ''Rhapsody in Blue Jeans'' *1983 - József Nepp creates the experimental feature-length film, ''[[Hófehér]]'' ("No-White")<ref name=kowe/> *1983 - [[Zsolt Richly]] creates ''[[Háry János]]'' *1984 - Gyula Nagy creates ''Süti'' ("Scones"), followed soon afterward by the 1986 experimental film, ''Ujjhullám'' ("Finger Wave"). *1984 - [[István Orosz]] creates the social message film, ''Ah, Amerika!'' ("Ah, America!"), for which he would win the 1985 [[Kecskeméti Animáció Film Fesztivál|KAFF]] Award for Best Script. He would go on to win KAFF awards in 1993 and 2005 when he was awarded the Grand Prix for ''Az idõ látképei'' ("Time Sights").<ref>''[http://culturehungary.org/index.php/events/details/a_wealth_of_difference_celebrating_hungarian_animation_and_graphic_art A Wealth Of Difference: Celebrating Hungarian Animation And Graphic Art - István Orosz in New York: Exhibition at the Hungarian Cultural Center]''. New York Hungarian House. 14 December 2011.</ref><ref>''[http://www.kaff.hu/2005/awards.html KAFF2005: Awards of the 7th Kecskemét Animation Film Festival]''. [[Kecskeméti Animáció Film Fesztivál|KAFF]]. 2005</ref> *1984 - Atilla Dargay creates the feature-length ''[[Szaffi]]'' ("Saffi")<ref name=kowe/> *1985 - The first tri-annual [[Kecskemét Animation Film Festival]] (Kecskeméti Animáció FilmFesztivál, or KAFF) is held in [[Kecskemét|Kecskemét, Hungary]].<ref name=napochka/><ref name=kaff/> *1986 - [[Béla Ternovszky]] creates the feature-length ''[[Macskafogó]]'' ("Cat City")<ref name=kowe/> *1987 - Béla Weisz creates ''Ajtó l'' ("Door I") *1987 - Sándor Reisenbüchler creates ''Isten veled kis sziget'' ("Farewell Little Island"), which pushes animation's visual artistry. *1987 - Ferenc Cakó creates a series of experimental animations starting with the sand animation, ''Ab ovo'', which won the [[Palme d'Or du court métrage]] for Animation at the Cannes Film Festival. This was followed by the 1989 experimental plasticine and coal powder animation, ''Ad rém'' ("Ad rem") *1988 - The second Kecskemét Animation Film Festival is held with notable animators such as John Halas serving on the selection jury.<ref name=lendvai2/> Organization problems delay the third such festival until 1993 and the festival resumes in 1996 when it was broadened to include international participants in the concurrently run Festival of European Animated Feature Films and TV-Specials ([[Európai Animációs Játékfilm Fesztival]]).<ref name=kaff/> *1989 - [[Zoltán Szilágyi Varga]] creates ''Ajtó 3'' ("Door 3") *1989 - Jánvári creates the experimental computer animated ''Labiritmus'' ("Labirythm")
===Current animation industry=== The end of the century saw the end of Communism in Hungary. Although state support for Hungary's one animation studio (Pannónia Film Stúdió) came to an end, the free market quickly prompted the development of a number of independent animation studios. In order to gain funding in the absence of the state, studios such as [[Kecskemétfilm|Kecskemétfilm Kft]] turn to employee ownership strategies while other studios work primarily as contractors for foreign markets doing work such as compositioning and inking.<ref name=dizseri/><ref name=howard/> Yet other studios such as the American-Hungarian joint venture [[Studio 2 (Hungary)|Studio 2]] have focused instead on traditional hand-drawn cell animation techniques to preserve this now niche animation style. Among other animation studios that were founded since the withdrawal of state control are included Pannónia rajzfilmgyártók, Videovox, Funny Film, Animex, Dana Film, Reflex, Puppet Film, Aladin stúdió, Firka, and the German-Hungarian joint venture Loonland. Several feature-length films have been released since the late 1980s including ''Albert mondja...'' ("Albert Says...") and ''Majmok kastélya'' ("Monkey Castle") among others. Animators who have risen to prominence since the end of the Communist era include Péter Szoboszlay, László Hegyi Füstös, Mária Horváth, Líviusz Gyulai, István Orosz, [[Dóra Keresztes]], László Haris, Péter Molnár, Zoltán Szilágyi Varga, Árpád Miklós, Gizella Neuberger, Béla Weisz, and László Ujváry.<ref name=lendvai/>
* 1988 - Independent animation studio, [[Varga Studio]], first begins to form from Egyetemi Színpadon's 1974 amateur animation collective, IXILON, under the efforts of Csaba Varga as government policies relax and the Communist era draws to a close.<ref name=howard/> * 1990 - State support for Pannónia Film Stúdió ends.<ref name=howard/> * 1991 - József Gémes creates the feature-length ''[[Hercegnő és a kobold]]'' ("The Princess and the Goblin") with a now-independent Pannónia Film Stúdió.<ref name=dizseri/> * 1991 - Pannónia Film Studio subsidiary, Kecskeméti Animációs Filmstúdió becomes an independent entity eventually taking the name Kecskemétfilm Kft under the leadership of Ferenc Mikulás. * 1992 - Independent studio, [[Magyar Rajzfilm]] is formed.<ref name=howard/> * 1993 - Two Kecskemétfilm animations are shortlisted for [[Cartoon d'or]] consideration: [[Zoltán Szilágyi Varga]]'s ''Éjszakai kultúrtörténeti hadgyakorlat'' ("Cultural Historical Manœuvre at Night") and Mária Horváth's ''Zöldfa utca 66'' ("66, Zöldfa Street") respectively. * 1996 - Kecskemétfilm releases ''Rege a csodaszarvasról'' ("Tale of the Miraculous Hind") * 1996 - Marcell Iványi creates ''Szél'' ("Wind"), winning a [[Palme d'Or du court métrage]] in Cannes. * 1998 - Studio 2 releases Zoltán Szilágyi Varga's ''Egérút'' ("Mouse Journey"), a feature-length film that was marketed internationally but which met with poor reception.<ref name=howard/> * 2001 - 3D [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]]-animation studio, [[Digic Pictures]] is founded to produce independent animations as well as animation for the video game industry. * 2002 - Pannónia Film Studio releases Marcell Jankovics's ''Csodaszarvas'' ("The Miraculous Hind") with funding from the [[Ministry of National Cultural Heritage (Hungary)|Ministry of National Cultural Heritage]].<ref name=howard/><ref name=lenburg/> * 2002 - Ági Mészáros creates ''Eső Után'' ("After Rain"), winning the Palme d'Or for Short Film at the 2002 Cannes Film Festival.<ref>''[https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/302770/Eso-Utan/details Eso Utan (2002)]''. Movies. New York Times. 2010.</ref> * 2004 - Varga Studio releases ''Csudafa'' ("Wonder Tree") under the direction of Péter Halász * 2004 - Áron Gauder and Erik Novák create ''[[Nyócker!]]'' ("The District!")<ref>Bori, Erzsebét. ''[http://www.hungarianquarterly.com/no180/6.html And Yet It Moves...: Áron Gauder and Erik Novák's Nyócker and the Revival of Hungarian Animation]''. The Hungarian Quarterly. No.180. 2005.</ref> * 2007 - Ádám Magyar creates the first freely downloadable 3D computer animated feature-film, ''[[Egon & Dönci]]'' * 2007 - Géza M. Tóth creates the [[79th Academy Awards|Oscar-nominated]] 3D animation, ''[[Maestro (2005 film)|Maestro]]''.<ref name=napochka/> * 2008 - György Gát directs the ''Kis Vuk'' ("Little Fox"); the sequel of the ''Vuk'' which was based on ''A Kis vuk és a Simabőrüek''. It was failed at the movie theaters, due the lack of graphic, the incoherent story. * 2009 - [[Rudolf Pap]] creates a music video for [[Kylie Minogue]]'s ''[[Speakerphone (Kylie Minogue song)|Speakerphone]]''.<ref>Minogue, Kylie. ''[http://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=148217403686 Kylie Speakerphone Competition Winner Announced!]'' Facebook. 5 October 2009.</ref> * 2011 - Magyar Rajzfilm releases ''[[Az ember tragédiája (film)|Az ember tragédiája]]'' ("The Tragedy of Man"), based on [[Imre Madách]]'s magnum opus.<ref name=lenburg/>

{{for|the historic demolished neighboring theater|Irving Place Theatre}} {{Infobox venue | name = Irving Plaza | image = Irving Plaza entrance.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = Entrance of venue (c. 2011) | nickname = | fullname = Irving Plaza, powered by Klipsch | address = 17 [[Irving Place|Irving Pl]]
[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|NY]] 10003-2392 | location = [[Union Square, Manhattan|Union Square]], [[Manhattan]] | coordinates = {{Coord|40|44|6|N|73|59|18|W|display=title,inline}} | type = | genre = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1978|07|14}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Polish Army Veterans Association of America | operator = [[Live Nation (events promoter)|Live Nation]] | construction_cost= | former_names = Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza {{small|(2007–2010)}} | seating_type = | seating_capacity = 1,200 | website = {{url|http://www.irvingplaza.com}} }} '''Irving Plaza''' (known through sponsorship as '''Irving Plaza, powered by Klipsch'''{{cite web |url=http://libn.com/2011/10/28/audiovox-subsidiary-klipsch-puts-name-on-amphitheater/ |title=Audiovox’s Klipsch puts name on amphitheater |author= |date=October 28, 2011 |website=[[Long Island Business News]] |publisher=The Dolan Company |accessdate=December 23, 2016}} and formerly known as the '''Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza''') is a [[ballroom]]-style music venue located within the [[Union Square (New York City)|Union Square]] neighborhood of [[Manhattan]] in [[New York City]]. It was featured on the ''Complex City Guide'' list of "50 Best Concert Venues of America" in 2013.{{cite web|last=Kimble|first=Jillian|title=The 50 Best Concert Venues In America|url=http://www.complex.com/city-guide/2013/05/the-50-best-concert-venues-in-america/irving-plaza|work=Complex City Guide|accessdate=31 May 2013}} == Polish Army veterans== The building was purchased by the Polish Army Veterans of America District 2 in 1948, and turned into a Polish-American community center. Generals and other distinguished Poles graced its stage including, in 1976, the future [[Pope John Paul II]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1976/09/05/archives/polish-cardinal-warmly-greeted-wojtyla-winds-up-his-tour-of-the-us.html "Polish Cardinal Warmly Greeted; Wojtyla Winds Up His Tour of the U.S. in New York"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (September 5, 1976) ==Rock venue== In 1978, the hall was converted to a [[rock music|rock]] music venue by future [[Peppermint Lounge]] promoters Tom Goodkind and Frank Roccio, who after a year began to share promotional efforts with a "Club 57" crew headed by Jane Friedman and Louis Tropia.Rockwell, John. [http://squattheatre.com/article04m.html "After Politics, There's Rock, Disco or Pop Clubs to Visit"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (August 8, 1980) -"Two organizations book concerts into the facility, with two different telephone numbers."{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/access/273446431.html?dids=273446431:273446431&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+02%2C+2003&author=Thomas+S.+Goodkind.&pub=Newsday+%28Combined+editions%29&desc=Survivors+of+the+Downtown+Scene%2C+Unite&pqatl=google | title=Survivors of the Downtown Scene, Unite | first=Thomas S. | last=Goodkind | date=2003-01-02}} Goodkind and Roccio brought in acts such as the [[B-52s]], [[Talking Heads]], the [[Ramones]] and, with Friedman and Tropia, a wealth of British bands, establishing the venue as a premier American location for [[punk rock|punk]] and [[New wave music|new wave]]. The venue was reopened by Chuck Terzella in October 1983,{{cite news |first=Pareles |last=Jon |authorlink=Jon Pareles |coauthors= |title=Rock: Devoto at Irving Plaze|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/arts/rock-devoto-at-irving-plaza.html |work= |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=October 5, 1983 |accessdate=2010-04-03}} with management by Frank Gallagher and the English DJ Andy Dunkley,{{cite news |url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/music/human-85.php |title=Human Jukebox |accessdate=2010-03-24 |last=Christgau |first=Robert|coauthors= |date= Jan 8, 1985 |publisher=Village Voice,}} presenting [[reggae]] and other ethnic music, plus [[college rock]], proclaiming in their ads "We don't have video".{{cite web |url=http://ephemeralnewyork.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/irvingplazaad1984.jpg |format=JPG |title=Display ad in the ''East Village Eye'' c. July 1984 |publisher=Ephemeralnewyork.files.wordpress.com}} Terzella's club filed for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|bankruptcy]] in December 1985, and closed in June 1986.{{cite news |title=Irving Plaza Rock Club Closes for Lack of Rent |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/06/07/arts/irving-plaza-rock-club-closes-for-lack-of-rent.html |work=Arts |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=June 7, 1986 |quote=''I used every resource I had to keep this place open for new music,'' he said. ''I'm tired, and I can't fight it anymore.'' |accessdate=2010-04-03}} Chris Williamson, who already promoted the punk and hard rock oriented "Rock Hotel" nights at the Ritz, then took over in November 1986.[http://www.sonicyouth.com/mustang/cc/sy112286.jpg Poster for Sonic Youth show November 22, 1986] He began programming [[alternative rock]] occasionally using the designation "Rock Motel". A New Year's Eve Rock Hotel show with [[The Dictators]] turned nasty after the band initiated a food fight and a bouncer lost his cool and beat some patrons.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HxsQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QIsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3475,425030&dq=irving-plaza+-display-ad+-classified-ad+-harlem&hl=en "Stop Breaking Down"] ''[[The Village Voice]]'' (January 13, 1987) Plans by the Polish Veterans to convert the building to condos fell through. They had to spend $25,000 on bringing the venue up to firecode before, in April 1987, Chris Williamson re-opened the club, featuring improved sound and lights, with an inaugural multi-night stand of [[Big Audio Dynamite]].{{cite web |url=http://andwhatsnext.com/bands/80s-artists/big-audio-dynamite/bowie-frampton-jimmy-cliff-dave-stewart-and-big-audio-dynamite |title=Bowie, Frampton, Jimmy Cliff, Dave Stewart and Big Audio Dynamite |accessdate=2010-03-24 }}{{cite news| title=Curtains|first=David|last= Browne| work=City Lights|publisher=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|date=December 25, 1988| url=https://archive.org/download/DailyNewscurtains-Dec251988/IrvingPlazacurtainsDailyNews.gif}} Williamson continued putting on shows into 1988—including hosting the popular "Milky Way" [[hip hop]] nights—but, as Irving Place gentrified, there was increasing local opposition to the hall. A plan by Williamson to present a play in the winter of 1988 fell through and, in December 1988, it was announced that the club would close and be demolished and turned into condos. The last show was The Ramones on December 31, 1988. Dee Dee Ramone praised the venue: "It was funky without being a dump." Ron Delsener took on management in the early 1990s. [[Live Nation]], a spinoff of [[Clear Channel Communications]], renovated and reopened Irving Plaza under the name "Fillmore New York At Irving Plaza" on April 11, 2007, reviving the name of the former [[Fillmore East]] in Manhattan's [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]], which had been open from 1968 to 1971.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9406E6DE1130F933A05750C0A9619C8B63|title=Arts, Briefly; New Name for Irving Plaza|work=[[New York Times]]|date=March 30, 2007|accessdate=2009-06-14|last=Sisario|first=Ben}} However, in May 2010 Live Nation conceded that the new name had not caught on and due to "unrelenting demand" the name "Irving Plaza" would be restored as from June 23, 2010. A replica of the original [[Marquee (sign)|marquee]] has been commissioned.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/01/arts/music/01irving.html|title=Rethinking, Irving Plaza Keeps Its Maiden Name |last1=Sisario |first1=Ben |last2= |first2= |date=May 31, 2010 |website=[[The New York Times]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |accessdate=December 23, 2016}} In September 2010, Irving Plaza became the venue for the services of [[Hillsong Church]] New York.[http://www.hillsongnyc.com/ hillsongnyc.com] On February 14, 2015, [[Paul McCartney]] played a surprise show announced only that morning on [[Twitter]].{{cite web | url = http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/02/15/paul-mccartney-s-v-day-serenade-beatles-legend-plays-1-000-person-star-studded-show-in-new-york.html | title = Paul McCartney’s V-Day Serenade: Beatles Legend Plays 1,000-Person Star-Studded Show in New York | work = Daily Beast | author = Jesse Lawrence | date = 2015-02-15 | accessdate = 2016-05-26 }} On May 25, 2016, 4 people were shot at a [[T.I.]] concert before T.I. took the stage. One of the victims died later at a hospital.{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/26/nyregion/people-are-shot-at-irving-plaza-during-ti-concert-police-say.html | title = One Fatally Shot and Three Wounded at T.I. Concert at Irving Plaza | work = NY Times | author = Christopher Mele | date = 2016-05-25 | accessdate = 2016-05-26 }} ==See also== [[House Of Blues]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Irving Plaza}} *{{official website|http://venue.irvingplaza.com/}} {{Live Nation}} [[Category:Nightclubs in Manhattan]] [[Category:Cultural history of New York City]] [[Category:Music venues in Manhattan]] [[Category:Drinking establishments in Manhattan]] [[Category:New York City nightlife]] [[Category:Companies that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 1985]] [[Category:Gramercy Park]]

page.title: KA MOUNTAIN AND GUARDenia TERRACE: a story about a family and some people changing
List of Colombian Academy Award winners and nominees

revision.text:
This is a '''list of [[Colombia]]n [[Academy Award]] winners and nominees'''. This list details the performances of Colombian filmmakers, actors, actresses and films that have either been submitted, nominated or have won an [[Academy Award]].
== Foreign Language Film category== {{Main|List of Colombian submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film}} This list focuses on Colombian films that won or were nominated for the foreign language film award.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left" |----- bgcolor="#bfd7ff" | colspan=6 align=center | '''[[Best Foreign Language Film]]''' |----- bgcolor="#ebf5ff" !width="030"|Year !width="130"|Film !width="100"|Director !width="075"|Status !width="450"|[[wikt:milestone|Milestone]]/Notes |- |2015||[[Embrace of the Serpent|''Embrace of The Serpent'']]|| [[Ciro Guerra]] ||{{nom}}|| First Colombian film to be nominated for an Academy Award. |}
==Best Actress – Leading Role== This list focuses on Colombian-born actors and actresses.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left" |----- bgcolor="#bfd7ff" | colspan=6 align=center | [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Actress]] |----- bgcolor="#ebf5ff" !width="030"|Year !width="130"|Name !width="100"|Film !width="075"|Status !width="450"|[[wikt:milestone|Milestone]]/Notes |- | 2004 || [[Catalina Sandino Moreno]]|| ''[[Maria Full of Grace]]'' ||{{nom}}|| First Colombian to be nominated for an Academy Award and first actress to be nominated for a Spanish-speaking role. |} ==Best Documentary Short Subject== This list focuses on documentaries directed by Colombian-born filmmakers.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left" |----- bgcolor="#bfd7ff" | colspan=6 align=center | [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Short Subject|Best Documentary Short Subject]] |----- bgcolor="#ebf5ff" !width="030"|Year !width="80"|Film !width="100"|Director !width="075"|Status !width="450"|[[wikt:milestone|Milestone]]/Notes |- | 2007 || ''[[La Corona (film)|La Corona]]'' || [[Isabel Vega]] || {{nom}} || |} ==See also== {{Portal|Colombia}} * [[Cinema of Colombia]] * [[List of Colombian films]]

{{Infobox company |name=Lithuania Bushido Federation
Lietuvos Bušido federacija |logo= |type= |genre= |predecessor= |foundation= 1999 |founder= |location_city=[[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]] |key_people=Donatas Simanaitis (president)
Col. Česlovas Jezerskas (honorary president) |industry=[[Mixed martial arts]] and [[kickboxing]] promotion |services= |parent= |homepage=http://www.bushido.lt |footnotes= |intl= }} '''Lithuania Bushido Federation''' ({{lang-lt|Lietuvos Bušido federacija}}), also known as '''Bushido Lithuania''', is the largest [[combat sports]] promotion in [[Lithuania]]. LBF was founded in 1999 with the name ''Lietuvos Bušido RINGS federacija'' as the Lithuanian stable-branch of the [[Japan]]ese promotion [[RINGS]] and held its first event in 2000. RINGS fighter [[Volk Han]] was influential in starting the promotion.{{cite web|url=http://bushido.lt/?id=10|title=Bushido.lt – Fighting network|website=bushido.lt}} As of 2012, LBF unites 34 Lithuanian sports clubs and has been holding the international [[mixed martial arts]] series ''Bushido Fighting Championship'', domestic MMA series ''S.W.A.T.'', international [[kickboxing]] series ''King of Kings'', international MMA series with [[Hero's]] Lithuania brand, as well as events carrying the brands of their partners such as [[K-1]], [[Shooto]], [[ADCC Submission Wrestling World Championship|ADCC]], [[Pancrase]], [[ZST]] and [[Shootboxing]]. This MMA organisation will partner [[Rizin Fighting Federation]] for the RIZIN FIGHTING WORLD GRAND-PRIX event to be held on December 29 and 31 2015. The former [[Pride Fighting Championships|Pride FC]] Heavyweight champion [[Fedor Emelianenko]] will headline the NYE Rizin FF main event.{{Cite web|title = Rizin FF - Rizin Fighting Federation 1|url = http://www.sherdog.com/events/Rizin-FF-Rizin-Fighting-Federation-1-48357|website = Sherdog|accessdate = 2015-11-26}}{{Cite web|title = Rizin FF - Rizin Fighting Federation 2|url = http://www.sherdog.com/events/Rizin-FF-Rizin-Fighting-Federation-2-48359|website = Sherdog|accessdate = 2015-11-26}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.sherdog.com/organizations/Bushido-Lithuania-1839 Bushido Lithuania events] at [[Sherdog]] ==See also== * [[King of Kings (kickboxing)|King of Kings]] {{MMA organizations}} {{Kickboxing organizations}} [[Category:Mixed martial arts organizations]] [[Category:Kickboxing organizations]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Lithuania]] [[Category:Organisations based in Vilnius]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Milton Griepp |birthname = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = c. {{birth year and age|1954}}<ref name="Comic Shop" /> | birth_place = [[Wisconsin]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Businessman, distributor, consultant | networth = | education = B.A., sociology, [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]<ref name=WhosWho>[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=GRIEPP%2c+MILTON Griepp profile], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928-1999''. Accessed August 10, 2018.</ref> | spouse = | website = | footnotes = | children = }} '''Milton Griepp''' (born c. 1954) is an American businessman who has spent the bulk of his career involved with [[American comic book]]s. He was the co-founder and CEO of [[Capital City Distribution]], a [[Direct market|distributor]] of comic books and related material, from 1980 to 1996. In 2001, he founded the online [[trade magazine]] ''[[ICv2]]'' and acts as its CEO.
== Biography == While attending the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] for a masters degree in [[sociology]], Griepp worked in the comics division of [[Wisconsin Independent News Distributors]], located in [[Madison, Wisconsin]].<ref name="Comic Shop">Gearino, pp. 79–81.</ref> When the company was purchased by [[Big Rapids Distribution]] in 1978, Griepp and his coworker John Davis were absorbed as well. They both lost their jobs when Big Rapids went bankrupt in 1980, and Griepp drew [[Unemployment benefits# United States|unemployment benefits]] for two months.<ref name="Comic Shop"/>
At that time, Davis approached him to propose a partnership as comic book distributors. They founded [[Capital City Distribution]] in April 1980 when Griepp was 26 years old.<ref name="Comic Shop"/> With Griepp as CEO, the new business absorbed some of Big Rapids' assets<ref name="ICv2" /><ref name=Booker>Booker, M. Keith, editor. ''Comics through Time: A History of Icons, Idols, and Ideas'' (ABC-CLIO, 2014), p. 929.</ref> and grew to be the largest comic book distributor in the United States.<ref name="Comic Shop109">Gearino, p. 109.</ref> Griepp crafted a monthly newsletter, ''Internal Correspondence'', which was sent to all of their retail customers.<ref>Gearino, p. 146.</ref> Their main rival, [[Diamond Comics Distributors]], overtook it in size through acquisitions in 1988.<ref name="Comic Shop109"/> That year, Capital City and Diamond represented at least 70% of the comic book distribution market.<ref>Duin, Steve & [[Mike Richardson (publisher)|Richardson, Mike]] (1998) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=MihlAAAAMAAJ&q=milton+griepp Comics: Between the Panels]''. [[Dark Horse Comics]]. Retrieved August 13, 2018</ref>
When trade magazine ''[[Hero Illustrated]]'' published a list of the 100 most important people in the comic industry in mid-1993, Griepp was ranked tenth because of his push for innovation in distribution technology.<ref>Staff ([[cover date]] September 1993), "Hero's Top 100 – The 100 Most Important People in Comics" ''[[Hero Illustrated]]'' #3 p82. [[Warrior Publications]]. [[Lombard, Illinois]].</ref> Griepp encouraged retailers to enter the [[Information Age|computer age]] and was the first to offer online reordering options. His position fell to number 19 the following year because of turmoil caused by a [[Comic book collecting#Bust of the speculator market|bursting bubble in the industry]].<ref>Staff ([[cover date]] September 1994), "Hero's Top 100 – The 100 Most Important People in Comics" ''[[Hero Illustrated]]'' #15 p62. [[Warrior Publications]]. [[Lombard, Illinois]].</ref> Diamond acquired Capital City in 1996 during a period of industry consolidation.<ref name="ICv2">[http://icv2.com/about/ "Who We Are: Milton Griepp," ICv2.com.] Accessed October 15, 2009.</ref><ref>"Davis and Former Capital City Employees Join Diamond," ''The Comics Journal'' #192 (Dec. 1996), pp. 13–15.</ref><ref>Gearino, p. 7.</ref>
After next working as a publishing and retailing consultant, in 1999–2000 Griepp ran Next Planet Over, a San Francisco-based e-commerce company.<ref name="ICv2" />
In 2001, he founded ''[[ICv2]]'' (''Internal Correspondence version 2''), an online [[trade magazine]] which also conducts annual industry conferences. Comic professionals consider his annual [[white paper]] on comic sales the industry standard.<ref>Reid, Calvin (July 16, 2014), "[https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/comics/article/63319-comics-graphic-novels-market-hit-870-million-in-2013.html Comics, Graphic Novels Market Hit $870 Million in 2013]," [[Publishers Weekly]]. Retrieved August 14, 2018</ref> Since then, Griepp has served as a board member for organizations such as the parent company of the digital comics distribution platform [[comiXology]], the non-profit [[Comic Book Legal Defense Fund]], and [[Free Comic Book Day]].<ref name="ICv2" /><ref name="BC list 1">[[Rich Johnston|Johnston, Rich]] (November 2012). "Top 100 Power List", ''[[Bleeding Cool]] Magazine'' #1 p. 92. [[Avatar Press]]. [[Rantoul, Illinois]].</ref> These roles led to him being ranked number 92 on ''[[Bleeding Cool]] Magazine''{{`s}} 2012 "Top 100 Power List" for the comic industry.<ref name="BC list 1"/>
== Further reading == * Interview in [[David Anthony Kraft]]'s ''Comics Interview'' #43 (Fictioneer Books, 1987)

[http://jamiecoville.com/blog/blog/2017/10/30/milton-griepp-interview/ "Milton Griepp Interview,"] JamieCoville.com (May 2004) * [https://funnybookfanatic.wordpress.com/2009/01/13/milton-griepp-capital-city-and-nearly-naked-television/#more-1874 "Milton Griepp, Capital City and nearly naked television,"] ''Funny Book Fanatic'' * [https://www.linkedin.com/in/milton-griepp-44788a2 Griepp's LinkedIn profile]

{{Infobox person | name = Moni Moshonov | image = Moni Moshonov.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = Moni Moshonov, 2006 | birthname = Shlomo Moshonov | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1951|8|18}} | birth_place = [[Ramla]], [[Israel]] | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | occupation = Actor, comedian, theatre director | yearsactive = 1977–present | spouse = Sandra Sadeh | domesticpartner = | website = | academyawards = | afiawards = | arielaward = | baftaawards = | cesarawards = | emmyawards = | filmfareawards = | geminiawards = | goldencalfawards = | goldenglobeawards = | goldenraspberryawards = | goyaawards = | grammyawards = | iftaawards = | laurenceolivierawards = | naacpimageawards = | nationalfilmawards = | sagawards = | tonyawards = | awards = {{awd|Ophir Award|2001|Late Marriage|Yasha}}{{awd|Ophir Award|2005|Ktsarim|}} }} '''Shlomo "Moni" Moshonov''' ({{lang-he-n|שלמה "מוני" מושונוב}}; born 18 August 1951) is an [[Israel]]i actor, comedian, and theater director.
==Life and career== Moshonov was born in [[Ramla]], [[Israel]] in 1951, to a family which [[Aliyah|immigrated]] to Israel from [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]]. His father, Moshe, who studied law in Sofia, sold textiles in the [[Ramla]] market.<ref name=fried>{{Cite news | last = Fried | first = Yaron | title = All for love | work = Haaretz | accessdate = 22 May 2009 | date = 21 May 2009 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1087242.html }}</ref> Moshonov grew up in Ramla. He did his military service in an [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] entertainment troupe. After studying drama at [[Tel Aviv University]], he joined the [[Haifa Theater]], remaining with the group for five years.<ref name=mooma>{{Cite web | title = Moni and Baraba | work = Mooma | accessdate = 18 May 2008 | url = http://mooma.keshet-tv.com/Biography.asp?ArtistId=16961 |language=he}}</ref> In 1977 he made his first film appearance in ''Masa Alunkot'' ("Journey of Stretchers") alongside [[Gidi Gov]].<ref name=fried/>
In 1978–98, Moshonov and [[Shlomo Baraba]] hosted the satirical TV show ''[[Zehu Ze!]]'', first on [[Israeli Educational Television]] and then [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]]. He also appeared in the films ''The Man Who Flew in to Grab'' (1981), ''[[Every Time We Say Goodbye (film)|Every Time We Say Goodbye]]'' (1986) and ''[[Deadline (1987 film)|Deadline]]'' (1987). During the 1980s he starred in five "Festigal" song festivals, performing children's songs. He also starred in [[Arik Einstein]]'s children's video ''Like Grownups'' in 1991. In 1992 he wrote, produced and starred in the film ''Cables''.<ref name=mooma/>
He has appeared in many theater plays in the [[Cameri Theater]], [[Habima]] and the [[Beit Lessin Theater]], as well as several entertainment shows with Baraba.<ref name=habama>{{Cite web | title = Moni Moshonov | work = Habama | accessdate = 18 May 2008 | date = 1 September 2004 | url = http://www.habama.co.il/Pages/ArtPerson.aspx?PeopleID=1 |language=he}}</ref> In 2006 he directed ''Ideal Wedding'' at Habima and starred in ''[[The Goat: or, Who Is Sylvia?]]''.<ref name=reichman>{{Cite news | last = Reichman | first = Alon | title = Moni superstar | work = msn | accessdate = 18 May 2008 | url = http://bidur.msn.co.il/msnEntertainment/TvAndRadio/Articles/200801/20080120113218.htm |language=he}}</ref><ref name=pinto>{{Cite news | last = Pinto | first = Goel | title = Curtains up and lights out | work = Haaretz | accessdate = 18 May 2008 | url = http://news.haaretz.co.il/hasen/pages/ShArtStEngPE.jhtml?itemNo=847308&contrassID=2&subContrassID=11&title='Curtains%20up%20and%20lights%20out%20'&dyn_server=172.20.5.5 }}</ref>
In 2000 he starred in ''Besame Mucho'' and in [[Dover Kosashvili]]'s ''[[Late Marriage (film)|Late Marriage]]'' in 2001, for which he won the [[Israeli Film Academy Ceremony|Israeli Film Academy]] Award for best supporting actor. In 2002 he starred in [[Amos Gitai]]'s ''[[Kedma (film)|Kedma]]''. In 2003 he played in Kosashvili's next film ''[[Gift from Above]]'', and starred in ''Year Zero''. In 2004 he joined the sketch show ''[[Ktzarim]]'' on the [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]], for which he won an Israeli Film Academy Award for best actor in a comedy series, and in 2007 he hosted the Israeli version of ''[[Thank God You're Here]]'' on [[Channel 10 (Israel)|Channel 10]]. In 2006 he starred in ''Forgiveness'' ("Mechilot") and in ''[[We Own the Night (film)|We Own the Night]]'' in 2007. In 2008 he joined the cast of the second season of ''[[Betipul]]'',<ref name=reichman/> and starred in ''[[Two Lovers (2008 film)|Two Lovers]]''.<ref name=fried/>
Moshonov is married to actress Sandra Sadeh and is the father of opera singer and actress [[Alma Sadé Moshonov]] and actor [[Michael Moshonov]].<ref name=zeev>{{Cite news | last = Ben Ze'ev | first = Noam | title = Almost famous | work = Haaretz | accessdate = 18 May 2008 | date = 17 May 2007 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/858204.html }}</ref> He lives in [[Tel Aviv]], near [[Habima Theater]].<ref>{{Cite news | last = Halutz | first = Doron | title = Star quality | work = Haaretz | accessdate = 26 January 2009 | date = 4 December 2008 | url = http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasen/spages/1041618.html }}</ref>
In 2012 he played in the Israeli TV series, ''[[The Gordin Cell]]'' as Peter Yom-Tov, an old [[Shin-Bet]] agent from [[Bulgaria]]. He co-starred as Nick in the 2013 movie ''[[Hunting Elephants]]''. In the same year, he appeared in ''[[Shraga Bishgada]]'', an Israeli TV show.
In 2014 he played in the Bulgarian film ''[[Bulgarian Rhapsody]]'', which became the Bulgarian entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[87th Academy Awards]].
In 2015 he portrayed former [[Bank of Israel]] governor [[Stanley Fischer]] in a controversial TV ad campaign for [[Amir Bramly]]'s Kela fund, which was broadcast in [[prime-time TV|Prime time]] including the "Golden Break" before the winner announcement in two high rating [[Reality television|reality shows]].<ref>[http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4696272,00.html "Stanley Fischer" will call investors to invest in new opportunities, Yediot, 2015-08-31]</ref><ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1001065338 Kela fund purchases the "Golden Break" in "Master Chef" And "The X Factor", Globes, 2015-08-31]</ref><ref>[http://www.ice.co.il/media/news/article/415150 Too late and too little? Because of the investigation, the 2nd TV authority won't allow additional broadcasting of Kela's Fund campaign, ICE, 2015-09-17]</ref>
